data.title: Dive into anything
data.text:
Thanks for all your woodland plant ideas this spring. I added more penstemon after that post. But we also talked asters. The question now is: Which aster?

The site is as follows:

20 ft long, narrow rectangle running along the sidewalk

30 degree slope

Rain and high winds in fall (tornado and hurricane seasons)

Drought in spring and summer.

Full sun on one end: Switchgrass, culver's root, beardstongue penstemon, and other tall plants.

Part sun in the middle: Baptisia australis, Zizia aurea, garden phlox, and Asclepias tuberosa

Part shade (four hours of morning sun) on the other end: Phlox divericata, foamflower, strawberry, calico penstemon

This shadier side is my problem area. It's dominated by ground cover. But I need tall plants since the rest of the garden is tall. I also need drought tolerance and ability to withstand high winds. I'd like to avoid plants that tend to take over small gardens, so I think zigzag goldenrod is no longer a contender.

I'm thinking about taller drought tolerant asters that can handle some shade. Specifically:

Symphyotrichum laeve (smooth aster)

Symphyotrichum oolentangiense (sky blue aster)

Runner up: Solidago rugosa (not an aster)

Anyone willing to share their experience with these plants in light shade or part shade?

ETA: Thank you all so much. I'm planting Solidago rugosa and smooth aster today, as it turns out that I'm out of range for sky blue. For heart leaved aster, I plan to winter sow and move the starts into the garden come spring.
